# Robin Ward (singer)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

[![Crystal Clear app
kedit.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Crystal_Clear_app_kedit.svg/40px-
Crystal_Clear_app_kedit.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Crystal_Clear_app_kedit.svg)|

help](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Robin_Ward_\(singer\)&action=edit).
The [discussion page](/wiki/Talk:Robin_Ward_\(singer\) "Talk:Robin Ward
\(singer\)") may contain suggestions. _(January 2018)_  
---|---  
Robin Ward  
---  
Birth name|  Jacqueline McDonnell  
Also known as|  Jackie Ward  
Born|  1941 (age 76–77)  
[Hawaii](/wiki/Hawaii "Hawaii"), [USA](/wiki/United_States "United States")  
Genres|  [Pop](/wiki/Pop_Music "Pop Music"), [TV theme
songs](/wiki/Theme_music "Theme music"), Movie songs, Advertising  
Occupation(s)|  [Singer](/wiki/Singer "Singer")  
Instruments|  Voice  
Years active|  1954–1979  
Labels|  [Dot Records](/wiki/Dot_Records "Dot Records")  
Associated acts|  [Partridge Family](/wiki/Partridge_Family "Partridge
Family"), [Ray Conniff Singers](/wiki/Ray_Conniff_Singers "Ray Conniff
Singers"), [Ron Hicklin Singers](/wiki/Ron_Hicklin_Singers "Ron Hicklin
Singers")  
  
**Jackie Ward** (born **Jacqueline McDonnell** , 1941), better known as
**Robin Ward** , is an American singer, regarded as a "[one-hit
wonder](/wiki/One-hit_wonder "One-hit wonder")" of 1963 million-selling song
"Wonderful Summer". However, using her real name she was highly accomplished
and successful singing in groups. Ward's voice is heard in U.S. television
series, motion pictures, advertisements, and pop records. She is one of the
real singers of the hits attributed to The Partridge Family.

## Contents

  * 1 Biography
    * 1.1 Early years
    * 1.2 "Wonderful Summer"
    * 1.3 Post "Robin Ward" TV, movies, and records singing
    * 1.4 The Partridge Family
  * 2 References
  * 3 External links

##
Biography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Robin_Ward_\(singer\)&action=edit&section=1&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Biography")]

### Early
years[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Robin_Ward_\(singer\)&action=edit&section=2&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Early years")]

Ward was born Jacqueline McDonnell in 1941 to a military family in
[Hawaii](/wiki/Hawaii "Hawaii") (her father served in the [US
Navy](/wiki/United_States_Navy "United States Navy")) and raised in
[Nebraska](/wiki/Nebraska "Nebraska"). Her first public singing performances
were with her two sisters in a Nebraska church when she was eight years old.
After the trio won a national talent search run by [Horace
Heidt](/wiki/Horace_Heidt "Horace Heidt"),[1] they moved to [Los
Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles") to seek work in the [music
industry](/wiki/Music_industry "Music industry").

At the age of 13, Ward was hired by Los Angeles television station
[KTLA](/wiki/KTLA "KTLA") to sing on a _[Your Hit
Parade](/wiki/Your_Hit_Parade "Your Hit Parade")_ -like program, _Bandstand
Revue_ ; Ward performed popular hits for four years. Then she started a career
of singing on demo and released recordings. One 1962 session was singing the
"la la la" parts in [Pat Boone](/wiki/Pat_Boone "Pat Boone")'s "[Speedy
Gonzales](/wiki/Speedy_Gonzales_\(song\) "Speedy Gonzales \(song\)")", which
became a million-selling single. ([Elton John](/wiki/Elton_John "Elton John")
said the "[hook](/wiki/Hook_\(music\) "Hook \(music\)")" in his best-selling
single "[Crocodile Rock](/wiki/Crocodile_Rock "Crocodile Rock")" was inspired
by Ward's "Speedy Gonzales" vocal.)[2]

### "Wonderful
Summer"[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Robin_Ward_\(singer\)&action=edit&section=3&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: "Wonderful Summer"")]

In 1963, songwriter-producer [Perry Botkin Jr.](/wiki/Perry_Botkin_Jr. "Perry
Botkin Jr.") hired Jackie Ward to make a demo recording of "Wonderful Summer",
a song he wrote with co-writer and co-producer Gil Garfield.[3] The purpose of
a demo is to persuade "name" singers to record a song by demonstrating how it
might be done. After recording Ward's vocal at [Gold Star
Studios](/wiki/Gold_Star_Studios "Gold Star Studios") in Los Angeles, Botkin
thought it might sound better if her voice was higher-pitched, so he sped up
the recording by wrapping splicing tape around the capstan of the machine.
Botkin realized the finished recording, with bird and surf sound effects
added, was good enough to release as a pop music single. But because the sped-
up singing sounded younger than 21-year-old Jackie Ward, she suggested using
her daughter's first name Robin on the record label. That fall, "Wonderful
Summer" was released by [Dot Records](/wiki/Dot_Records "Dot Records") as a
45rpm single. Sales exceeded one million copies in the United States,
propelling the record to #14 on the [Billboard Hot
100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100") chart of December 14–21,
1963.[4]

An album followed, with limited success. Jackie Ward made additional "Robin
Ward" recordings, including a duet with radio DJ [Wink
Martindale](/wiki/Wink_Martindale "Wink Martindale"), another Dot Records
artist. In 1964 Ward released the single "Winter's Here", which reached #123
on the Billboard chart. Because "Wonderful Summer" is her only Hot 100 hit,
the singer named Robin Ward is considered a one-hit-wonder. However, while the
public did not know Jackie's real name, many of her other recordings were and
still are widely heard.

### Post "Robin Ward" TV, movies, and records
singing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Robin_Ward_\(singer\)&action=edit&section=4&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Post "Robin Ward" TV, movies, and records singing")]

As her young-sounding Robin Ward records were disappearing from radio play,
Jackie Ward's grown-up singing career was expanding. At times in 1960s-1970s
she could be heard almost everywhere.

In the early to mid-1960s Jackie was one of the singers on _[The Red Skelton
Show](/wiki/The_Red_Skelton_Show "The Red Skelton Show")_ and _[The Danny Kaye
Show](/wiki/The_Danny_Kaye_Show "The Danny Kaye Show")_ , and later, on _[The
Carol Burnett Show](/wiki/The_Carol_Burnett_Show "The Carol Burnett Show")_.
In the 1970s she sang on _[The Sonny& Cher Comedy
Hour](/wiki/The_Sonny_%26_Cher_Comedy_Hour "The Sonny & Cher Comedy Hour")_.

Ward sang in hundreds of commercials, most notably for [Rice-a-
Roni](/wiki/Rice-a-Roni "Rice-a-Roni") ("The San Francisco treat").

Ward's voice is heard in dozens of television theme songs, including
_[Flipper](/wiki/Flipper_\(1964_TV_series\) "Flipper \(1964 TV series\)")_ ,
_[Batman](/wiki/Batman_\(TV_series\) "Batman \(TV series\)")_ , _[Love,
American Style](/wiki/Love,_American_Style "Love, American Style")_ ,
_[Maude](/wiki/Maude_\(TV_series\) "Maude \(TV series\)")_ (with [Donny
Hathaway](/wiki/Donny_Hathaway "Donny Hathaway") providing the lead vocal),
and _[The Partridge Family](/wiki/The_Partridge_Family "The Partridge
Family")_.

By her own estimate, Ward's voice can be heard in "maybe 800" films. Among the
notable are her voice dubbed as [Natalie Wood](/wiki/Natalie_Wood "Natalie
Wood") singing Academy Award-nominated song "[Sweetheart
Tree](/w/index.php?title=Sweetheart_Tree&action=edit&redlink=1 "Sweetheart
Tree \(page does not exist\)")" from movie _[The Great
Race](/wiki/The_Great_Race "The Great Race")_ , as Wood in _[Inside Daisy
Clover](/wiki/Inside_Daisy_Clover "Inside Daisy Clover")_ , and as [Janet
Leigh](/wiki/Janet_Leigh "Janet Leigh") in _[An American
Dream](/wiki/An_American_Dream_\(film\) "An American Dream \(film\)")_. Ward
is the singing voice of [Cindy Bear](/wiki/Cindy_Bear "Cindy Bear") in _[Hey
There, It's Yogi Bear!](/wiki/Hey_There,_It%27s_Yogi_Bear! "Hey There, It's
Yogi Bear!")_, and the Singer in [_Charlotte 's
Web_](/wiki/Charlotte%27s_Web_\(1973_film\) "Charlotte's Web \(1973 film\)").
In 1965 movie _[Beach Blanket Bingo](/wiki/Beach_Blanket_Bingo "Beach Blanket
Bingo")_ , Ward sings "New Love" and "Fly Boy", lip-synched by actor [Linda
Evans](/wiki/Linda_Evans "Linda Evans").

Along with her TV, movie and advertising singing, Ward is heard on hundreds of
pop recordings, including backing [Barbra Streisand](/wiki/Barbra_Streisand
"Barbra Streisand") on "[Stoney End](/wiki/Stoney_End_\(song\) "Stoney End
\(song\)")". and other major recording artists including [Nat King
Cole](/wiki/Nat_King_Cole "Nat King Cole"), [Bing Crosby](/wiki/Bing_Crosby
"Bing Crosby"), [Frank Sinatra](/wiki/Frank_Sinatra "Frank Sinatra"), [Gordon
Lightfoot](/wiki/Gordon_Lightfoot "Gordon Lightfoot"), [the
Carpenters](/wiki/The_Carpenters "The Carpenters"), [Cass
Elliot](/wiki/Cass_Elliot "Cass Elliot"), and [Joan Baez](/wiki/Joan_Baez
"Joan Baez"). Ward did broadcast recordings of musicals _Hair_ , _Grease_ ,
_Annie_ , and _Hello Dolly_. Ward sang a duet with Allan Sherman on his song
_Here 's To the Crabgrass_ from his 1963 comedy album _My Son The Nut_. In
1967, she sang on [Gábor Szabó](/wiki/G%C3%A1bor_Szab%C3%B3 "Gábor Szabó")'s
album for Impulse!, _Wind, Sky And Diamonds_ , as a member of The California
Dreamers.

Ward also sang alto in vocal groups heard on many hit records and popular
albums, including [the Anita Kerr Singers](/wiki/The_Anita_Kerr_Singers "The
Anita Kerr Singers") and [the Ron Hicklin
Singers](/wiki/The_Ron_Hicklin_Singers "The Ron Hicklin Singers") (who
anonymously made many hit records beyond the Partridge Family). As a member of
[the Ray Conniff Singers](/wiki/The_Ray_Conniff_Singers "The Ray Conniff
Singers"), Ward recorded several lead and solo vocals.

### The Partridge
Family[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Robin_Ward_\(singer\)&action=edit&section=5&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: The Partridge Family")]

Ward's longest-lasting contribution might be _[The Partridge
Family](/wiki/The_Partridge_Family "The Partridge Family")_ TV show and hit
records, where she is heard but not seen or identified. Other than show star
[David Cassidy](/wiki/David_Cassidy "David Cassidy") (and star [Shirley
Jones](/wiki/Shirley_Jones "Shirley Jones") on a couple of songs), none of the
actors participated in singing or playing the songs; on camera they lip-synced
and pretended to play instruments while the soundtrack is actually recordings
by session musicians. Ward was in the Ron Hicklin Singers vocal group, along
with brothers [John Bahler](/wiki/John_Bahler "John Bahler") and [Tom
Bahler](/wiki/Tom_Bahler "Tom Bahler"), and [Ron Hicklin](/wiki/Ron_Hicklin
"Ron Hicklin"). With Cassidy singing lead, this group did all the TV show
performances and records credited to the Partridge Family (along with session
instrumental musicians who became known as [the Wrecking
Crew](/wiki/The_Wrecking_Crew_\(music\) "The Wrecking Crew \(music\)")). Since
the public did not know who really created the many Partridge Family songs
that became big hits, Ward again was anonymous.
